user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtList_DeleteNode:
```c
void UtList_DeleteNode(UtListNode_t *DeleteNode)
{
    UtList_Extract(DeleteNode);

    /* non-data/header nodes shouldn't be free()'ed */
    if (DeleteNode->Data != NULL)
    {
        free(DeleteNode);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UtList_DeleteNode:
void UtList_Extract(UtListNode_t *ExistingNode)
{
    ExistingNode->Next->Prev = ExistingNode->Prev;
    ExistingNode->Prev->Next = ExistingNode->Next;
    ExistingNode->Next       = ExistingNode;
    ExistingNode->Prev       = ExistingNode;
}
...
void UtList_Reset(UtListNode_t *TagHead)
{
    while (!UtList_IsEmpty(TagHead))
    {
        UtList_DeleteNode(TagHead->Next);
    }
}
...
void UtList_Destroy(UtListHead_t *ListHead)
{
    uint32 i;

    for (i = 0; i < ListHead->NumberOfTags; ++i)
    {
        UtList_Reset(&ListHead->Tags[i]);
    }
    free(ListHead);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I found no uses of any <string.h> functions in the provided code. MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 specifically concerns calls to the standard string handling functions (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.). The shown functions — UtList_DeleteNode, UtList_Extract, UtList_Reset, and UtList_Destroy — perform pointer manipulations and calls to free(), but do not call any of the listed string.h routines. Therefore there are no code fragments that could violate Rule 21.17 and nothing here needs to be investigated for that specific rule. (If you want, separate checks could be run for other MISRA rules such as pointer validity or use-after-free, but those are outside the scope of Rule 21.17.)
